notes: Ana reflects on how blogging has been part of her life since the early 2000s.

author: Ana Rodrigues
description: Ana's personal blog
notes: Ana starts to over think her blog and needs to get it back on track.

title: Letting Go of the Old Web
author: Desiree
description: Last year I wrote a thing on Automattic’s design blog about something I keep noodling on, which ultimately boils down to what makes us creative. What gets us to build a website? What the hell…
notes: Desiree explores what gets us to build a website and tries to understand what a website actually is today.

title: Overthinking my nostalgia
author: Ana Rodrigues
description: Ana's personal blog
notes: Ana reflects on her nostalgia for the old web and what she can learn from it.

title: manifesto
author: sadgrl
description: The old web refers to the internet's former iteration. It includes Web 1.0 and the early parts of Web 2.0. It is known as the age of chat rooms, message boards, Myspace and Livejournal.
notes: The page that started a... something... We, the people of the Internet, have the power to restore it to its former glory.

title: Make your own independent website
notes: Victoria shares how to make 2021 the year of the independent web....

title: sadgrl | There's no place like the old internet
notes: I started on the Internet back in 1996. Sadness came later. In this blog post she explores what the old web looks like compared to the new web.

title: I Made a Linguistics Professor Listen to a Blink-182 Song and Analyze the Accent
description: Two decades have passed since pop-punk exploded in the American music scene, yet the quintessentially suburban, teen-centric music still seems to bounce...
notes: A linguistics professors analysis of the american pop punk accent. Great read.

title: One Terabyte of Kilobyte Age | Digging through the Geocities Torrent
notes: Digging through the Geocities Torrent

title: Ruins and Templates of Geocities
notes: The free web hosting service GeoCities was founded by Beverly Hills Internet in July 1995, which exactly corresponds with the moment that the web left academia and started to become accessible to everyone. Users began learning Hyper Text Markup Language, and welcomed each other onto their “home pages” — the first personal websites,

title: GeoCities, webrings, and the cozy connectedness of the ‘90s internet
description: Believe it or not, the internet used to feel a lot cozier. In the early days of the World Wide Web, as many of us called it back then, going online was like exploring the Wild West. In those days, seeking out the content you wanted online wasn't…
notes: How GeoCities webrings made the ‘90s internet a cozier place.

title: A love letter to my website - DESK Magazine
description: This is a declaration of love for personal websites, written from years of thinking on the subject, reviewing thousands of portfolios, building websites for friends and bookmarking those of strangers. It’s a subject I’m so passionate about, I built my business on it. And recently, it’s become a matter of principle. Not long ago, the …
notes: A declaration of love for personal websites.

title: Ten Commandments of the Small Internet
description: A grassroots Internet movement called
notes: A grassroots Internet movement called \"the small Internet\" is afoot. Here are ten commandments that Cheapskates would like to see largely obeyed on the small Internet.

title: What I Learned about the Internet by Creating My Own Website
description: Here are some things I learned about the Internet by creating my own website.
notes: Here are some things Cheapskates learned about the Internet by creating their own website.

title: Nostalgia Is Bullshit
notes: When you come to the realisation that web 1.0 nostalgia is bullshit. September shares with us their thoughts about web 1.0 design nostalgia. Like all nostalgia, it's bullshit.

title: The Return of the 90s Web
author: Max Böck
description: Are we ready to revisit some of the ideas of the early web again? There are trends that suggest we might just have come full circle - and I like it.
notes: Max wonders if having your own website is trendy again.

title: Seven Reasons for having a Personal Website
description: There are at least seven reasons you should have a personal website.
notes: There are at least seven reasons you should have a personal website. Cheapskates lets us know what they are.

title: The Missing Hit and the Open Web
author: Jim Nielsen
description: Writing about the big beautiful mess that is making things for the world wide web.
notes: If it doesn't appear in google's search results, does it really exist?

title: Making the Web Fun Again
description: Ever since I visited my first web site (via a slow modem to a library BBS running a text-based web browser), I have been ceaselessly pondering the nature of ...
notes: Kyle looks at how the web could be made fun again.

title: Underscores, Optimization & Arms Races - Anil Dash
author: undefined
description: A blog about making culture. Since 1999.
notes: A dozen years ago, the web started to reshape itself around major companies like Google. We can understand the genesis of today’s algorithmic arms race against the tech titans just by looking at a single character...

title: The modern web is becoming an unusable, user-hostile wasteland
description: Some thoughts about the modern web
notes: The question is: at which point do we reach the breaking point?

title: I Miss the Old Internet
author: Tie
description: I miss the internet of the early 1990's.
notes: The author, Tie, misses the Internet of the early 1990's.

title: Autonomy Online: A Case For The IndieWeb — Smashing Magazine
description: There is an alternative to corporate bubbles online — it’s called the IndieWeb. Build your own personal websites, control your online presence, and learn on your own terms.
notes: There is an alternative to corporate bubbles online — it’s called the indieweb. build your own personal websites, control your online presence, and learn on your own terms.

title: Hunting the Nearly-Invisible Personal Website
description: Personal websites have become nearly invisible on the Internet. This article suggests a few techniques for finding them.
notes: Cheapskates goes hunting. The personal website is a somewhat mysterious animal that lives mostly unobserved in the jungle of the Internet

title: ZeroNet and the Future of the Internet
description: A ZeroNet review that also asks, is ZeroNet the future of the Internet?
notes: Cheapskates again takes a dive into alternet Internet protocols... Until recently, the conventional wisdom was that the Internet is beyond the control of governments. how naive the conventional wisdom sometimes is.

title: The Rise And Fall Of Grunge Typography
description: The Rise And Fall Of Grunge Typographyby Sharan ShettyHop on the nostalgia train for a second. Think back to the 90s. To Nirvana, Linklater’s Slacker, and the flannel-clad rebels on the run from the 80s. To skateboards  ...

title: Everyone Should Have Access to the Web - The History of the Web
author: Jay Hoffmann
description: The World Wide Web Foundation began as a way to bring the web to everyone. In these trying times, it is needed more than ever.
notes: The World Wide Web Foundation began as a way to bring the web to everyone. In these trying times, it is needed more than ever.

title: When the Web Was Weird
description: In the late ‘90s, an obscure site called Superbad pioneered jarringly bizarre, often ugly, but occasionally beautiful web design. It’s taken all this time for the rest of the internet to catch up.
notes: In the late ‘90s, an obscure site called Superbad pioneered jarringly bizarre, often ugly, but occasionally beautiful web design. It’s taken all this time for the rest of the Internet to catch up.

author: Jay Hoffmann
description: In an interview for her book Internet Art in 2004, writer Rachel Greene had this to say about why she felt […]
notes: In an interview for her book Internet Art in 2004, writer Rachel Greene had this to say about why she felt...

title: To Mend a Broken Internet, Create Online Parks
author: Condé Nast
description: We need public spaces, built in the spirit of Walt Whitman, that allow us to gather, communicate, and share in something bigger than ourselves.
notes: We need public spaces, built in the spirit of Walt Whitman, that allow us to gather, communicate, and share in something bigger than ourselves...

title: The year we wanted the internet to be smaller
author: Kaitlyn Tiffany
description: Why tiny, weird online communities made a comeback in 2017
notes: Why tiny, weird online communities made a comeback in 2017.

title: How Social Media Killed Internet Art Communities
author: Kelsey Ables
description: Zany, early creative communities like DeviantArt and conceptart.org have been steamrolled by homogenous social media platforms.
notes: Zany, early creative communities like DeviantArt and conceptart.org have been steamrolled by homogenous social media platforms

title: Exit Feeds, Enter Community
description: Information floods the internet. You can’t control it, but it must be controlled for you to absorb it. It is primarily controlled through infinite feeds of content on social media. Because si…
notes: Information floods the internet. You can't control it, but it must be controlled for you to absorb it. It is primarily controlled through infinite feeds of content on social media....

title: He Created the Web. Now He’s Out to Remake the Digital World. (Published 2021)
description: Tim Berners-Lee wants to put people in control of their personal data. He has technology and a start-up pursuing that goal. Can he succeed?
notes: Tim Berners-Lee wants to put people in control of their personal data. He has technology and a start-up pursuing that goal. Can he succeed

title: One Startup’s Vision to Reinvent the Web for Better Privacy
description: Blockstack’s system would let you control your own personal data—for example, by revoking a site’s access to it.
notes: Blockstack’s system would let you control your own personal data—for example, by revoking a site’s access to it...

title: The Organic Web
author: Jim Nielsen
description: Writing about the big beautiful mess that is making things for the world wide web.
notes: There was a time when owning digital space seemed thrilling, and our personal sites motivated us to express ourselves. There are signs of a resurgence, but too few wish to make their digital house a home... People talk about growing communities and growing brands, but does anyone talk about growing a website?

title: Why can't I write code inside my browser?
description: Tom Critchlow. Move. Think. Create.
notes: So I can write code inside my spreadsheet, but not inside my browser? WTF!

title: It’s Time to Get Personal
description: Laura Kalbag discusses the gift of personal data we give to Big Tech when we share information on its platforms, and how reviving ye olde personal website can be one way to stay in control of the content we share and the data we leak. Christmas is a time for giving, but know what you’re giving to whom.
notes: Is it just me or does nobody have their own website anymore? Outdated sites, or sites that only contain a list of links to social media profiles on big tech platforms don't count. Despite being people who build websites, who love to share on the web, we don’t share much on our own sites

title: How to bring back the old internet
description: Section 230 has outlived its usefulness
notes: People who grew up with the internet of the 1990s probably remember forums — those clunky, lo-fi spaces where people came together to argue about cars, cycling, video games, cooking, or a million other topics. They had their problems, but in retrospect the internet of those days felt like a magical land of possibility, not a place for organizing pogroms.

title: Let's bring Fan Sites and webrings back! - bryanlrobinson.com
description: In the days before the web was mainstream, it was a place of creation. First for education, then for every random idea that any creator had! As the web transitioned from a network of educational institutions to the consumer force it is today, the early adopters were technologists... AKA geeks!
notes: In the days before the web was mainstream, it was a place of creation. First for education, then for every random idea that any creator had! As the web transitioned from a network of educational institutions to the consumer force it is today, the early adopters were technologists...

title: What happened to the ‘old internet’? We used to have so much variety and choice – it's all collapsed, or has it?
author: Techaeris
description: The internet brings the world into people’s homes, enabling people to interact with worldwide events in a way that television can’t. What's changed?
notes: The Internet brings the world into people’s homes, enabling people to interact with worldwide events in a way that television can’t. What's changed?

title: 2015 is the year the old internet finally died
author: Emily St. James
description: The old blogosphere is being eaten alive by the rise of social media and the mobile web.
notes: The old blogosphere is being eaten alive by the rise of social media and the mobile web.

title: How the Blog Broke the Web
description: I first got online in 1993, back when the Web had a capital letter — three, in fact — and long before irony stretched its legs and unbuttoned its flan
notes: The author first got online in 1993, back when the Web had a capital letter — three, in fact — and long before irony stretched its legs and unbuttoned its flannel shirt. Back when you could really say you were surfing the net...

title: Statistically obsessed
description: Measure, analyze, check your stats, take a look at the insights. Whether you are running a business website, a personal blog, a Twitter account or a Facebook page, there is someone breathing down y...
notes: Measure, analyze, check your stats, take a look at the insights. Whether you are running a business website, a personal blog, a Twitter account or a Facebook page, there is someone breathing down your neck asking about the numbers...

title: 404 Page Not Found | Kate Wagner
description: The artifacts of internet life are personal—that is, not professionally or historically notable—and therefore worthless.
notes: The artifacts of internet life are personal—that is, not professionally or historically notable—and therefore worthless...

title: The Old Internet Died And We Watched And Did Nothing
author: Katie Notopoulos
description: It’s 2020 — do you know where your content is?
notes: Quick: Can you think of a picture of yourself on the internet from before 2010, other than your old Facebook photos? How about something you’ve written? Maybe some old sent emails in Gmail or old Gchats? Thankfully I can. This article explores this more.

title: Web 0.5
description:
A few people have already used "Web 0.5" by back-construction from Web 2.0.  Sean Coates used it derogatively of MySpace, but this O'Reilly blog post is more positive, suggesting Web 2.0 is a return to earlier Internet applications.

But if Web 2.0 was about interactivity and collaboration in a comm
notes: A few people have already used Web 0.5 by back-construction from Web 2.0. Sean Coates used it derogatively of MySpace, but this O'Reilly blog post is more positive, suggesting Web 2.0 is a return to earlier Internet applications.

title: Yahoo, the Destroyer
author: Kaitlyn Tiffany
description: How the historic company became known as a bumbling villain of internet culture
notes: How the historic company became known as a bumbling villain of internet culture

title: You Probably Don’t Remember the Internet
author: Kaitlyn Tiffany
description: How do we memorialize life online when it’s constantly disappearing?
notes: How do we memorialize life online when it's constantly disappearing?

title: How to Make a Website
author: Kaitlyn Tiffany
description: wikiHow embodies an alternative history of the internet, and an interesting possibility for its future.
notes: wikiHow embodies an alternative history of the internet, and an interesting possibility for its future.

title: This used to be our playground
description: There was a time when owning digital space seemed thrilling, and our personal sites motivated us to express ourselves. There are signs of a resurgence, but too few wish to make their digital house a home.
notes: There was a time when owning digital space seemed thrilling, and our personal sites motivated us to express ourselves. There are signs of a resurgence, but too few wish to make their digital house a home.

title: I Got The Internet Going Nutz: Kreayshawn and 10 Years of SOMETHIN' BOUT KREAY' - MGRM
author: Jacqueline Codiga
description: Ten years after the release of Kreayshawn's SOMETHIN' BOUT KREAY', there are plenty of lessons to be learned about the era and the music.
notes: This article reflects on the 10th anniversary of rapper Kreayshawn's debut album Somethin Bout Kreay and how it marked a significant moment in internet culture. Kreayshawn really had it hard. She blew up on the Internet before there was a means to monitise it. It dives into the troubles she faced with the virality and her eventual departure from the spotlight.

title: 2023, the year of websites
author: Andy Bell
description: 2023 is going to be the year of websites—specifically personal websites—and I'm here for it. It seems like the momentum for people to hyper-focus (or re-focus) on their personal home on the World W…
notes: 2023 will be the year of websites as people become more aware of the value of owning their content and digital identity. Andy, like myself, encourages everyone to start building their own websites to have more control over their online presence and the ability to showcase their work. Check out the article for tips and resources for building your own website.

title: Build your metadata library
author: Katy DeCorah
description: Last year, I started to track new recipes I tried and books I read by saving their metadata to YAML files. I had already been saving Spotify playlists in the...
notes: This has kept me busy for the past 6 weeks. Katy explains the importance of metadata in web development and provides a step-by-step guide on creating and managing metadata using Github actions. She also emphasizes the need for developers to prioritize metadata in their workflow and explains how it can help improve search engine optimization and accessibility of websites. One thing that I have found while implementing my own metadata library is that metadata could be a lot better. I've had to do a lot of manual editing to get things looking nice.

title: Organizing the Eleventy config file
author: Lene Saile
description: Eleventy lets you create a file called eleventy.js to configure the SSG to your own project's needs. This article is all about organizing your config file!
notes: Lene dives deep and discusses how you could approach organising your Eleventy config file.

title: Firefox found a way to keep ad-blockers working with Manifest V3
author: Mitchell Clark
description: It plays nice with uBlock Origin.

title: Is Amos Burton a Sociopath?
author: Lane Zumoff
description: If you're reading this you're probably a fan of Amazon Prime's hit series The Expanse. If not, and you're simply wondering who Amos Burton is and why people are calling him names
notes: At first glance yup, but this article dives deeper to discover that Amos is indeed a complex person.

title: Sonos / Spotify Vinyl Emulator
description: Experience the tactile nature of a vinyl music collection (but without actually owning any vinyl) through Sonos, Spotify and NFC tags By Mark Hank.
note: Have you ever wanted to build a vinyl emulator? This post will guide you through doing exactly that with a Raspberry Pi, a USB turn table and a Sonos sound system. Play vinyl records on the Sonos system and control the turntable remotely through the web.

title: How to fix the internet
author: Paul J Miller
notes: Written in 2015. Should the tech giants control user-created content like videos, podcasts, music and blogs? Think of a web where standard and open formats such as .video, .podcast, .blog, and .tweet exist. They are not tied to apps rented to you by the tech giants. An entire ecosystem exists for users to choose how to consume this open and free content. I love these ideas and would love to work on something to push this...

title: Maybe the web should die
author: Paul J Miller
notes: Written in 2015, this seems even more relevant today in 2023. The Web shouldn't die, but content that exists solely to sell ads should. The current state of the Web is problematic due to issues like surveillance capitalism, monopolies, and social media's negative impact. Show the Web in its current form die so that something better can emerge in its place? This article is another call for people to take ownership of their data and participate in building a better web.

title: The Year of the Personal Website
author: Matthias Ott
description: Matthias Ott is an independent user experience designer and developer from Stuttgart, Germany. Besides design practice he teaches Interface Prototyping at the Muthesius Academy of Fine Arts and Design, Kiel.
notes: Have you heard me say 'create your own homepage!' before? Make 2023 the year we take back the web!

title: Own your stuff
author: Bryce Wray
description: Because the only constant is change, you shouldn't depend on others to keep your content online.
notes: Another article stresses the importance of owning and controlling your digital content rather than relying on social media or other platforms. Owning your content gives control over its distribution and longevity and reduces the risk of losing it due to how the tech giants feel about a particular service. Bryce offers practical tips and tools to create and host your own website or blog.

title: Blasts from the past
author: Bryce Wray
description: To save you the trouble, I revisit previous posts in search of useful info.
notes: Is the Internet broken, or has the way use it created the issues we see today? We could all take accountability for how we engage with content on the Internet and each other to avoid things such as sharing misleading or false information and work to make the Internet a better place for everyone.

title: There Can Be Money in Blogging - Chris Coyier
author: Chris Coyier
description: When you hear me endlessly prattle on about how you should have your own site, publish your own feed, and the general power of writing, I mean it. But why? What's the point of writing on your own site? So many. Not to mention it's fun! But there can be money in blogging too: You […]
notes: I don't care for the making money parts, but the other points are solid.

title: The internet is not broken. People are. - Manu
author: Manu
description: That magical place that is Hacker News managed to fish up this piece of content today, from the depths of the web. And I am very grateful for that. …

title: Welcome to the new Verge
author: Nilay Patel
description: A complete redesign of The Verge that marries the best of old-school blogging with a modern news feed experience.
notes: I'm interested to see how this works out for The Verge. Their redesign aims to provide a better user experience by improving the navigation, reducing clutter, and emphasizing the content. I've enjoyed reading so far and paying attention to who the authors of the blog posts are.

title: Bring back personal blogging
author: Monique Judge
description: The personal blog built the internet, and maybe it can fix it.
notes: I whole heartedly agree with the message in this post, I share similar thoughts in my manifesto.

title: In Defense of a Fussy Website
author: Sarah Drasner
description: The other day I was doom-scrolling twitter, and I saw a delightful article titled “The Case for Fussy Breakfasts.” I love food and especially breakfast, and
notes: It is evident when a website has been crafted with care and excitement. It can enhance user experience and improve the overall perception of a brand. I love discovering new websites where the webmaster has done just that. It's great to stand out from the crowd and helps me identify whether a real person is behind the website.

title: Just Put Stuff Out There
author: Matthias Ott
description: Matthias Ott is an independent user experience designer and developer from Stuttgart, Germany. Besides design practice he teaches Interface Prototyping at the Muthesius Academy of Fine Arts and Design, Kiel.
notes: We all fall trap to this. Create and share your work with the world instead of holding back and waiting for perfection. Putting oneself out there and learning from mistakes is essential to the creative process. Learning in public is one of the fun things about the Web.

title: A Web that Reflects People and their Val… — Jacky Alciné
author: Jacky Alciné
notes: Dive into the current state of the internet and the rise of decentralised projects attempting to offer an alternative to the tech giants. Jacky expresses their desire for an alternative social networking system that allows them to publish and share content while maintaining control over their data. I like emphasising this exact message in every conversation about posting your content online.

title: Why is your site like this?
author: Di
notes: Fellow small web enthusiast Di explores why they write, including the desire to create something beautiful and meaningful, the need to process their thoughts and emotions, and the hope to connect with others through their writing. Writing is an act of self-discovery and a way to make sense of the world around them.

title: Smashmouth's White Magic
author: Zach Mandeville
description: Older esoteric standup piece
notes: Zach dives into Smashmouth's hidden, mystical significance, particularly the references to hermetic alchemy in their music. It hilariously ends with a warning of the dangers of bands like Third Eye Blind, who use the occult arts to obfuscate and block spiritual clarity.

title: A Web Renaissance
author: Anil Dash
description: A blog about making culture. Since 1999.
notes: Written in 2022, Anil declares the internet is experiencing a new wave of innovation and creativity, similar to the early days of the web. Dash cites the proliferation of web-based apps, the rise of decentralized technologies like blockchain, and the increasing focus on privacy and security as signs of this renaissance. He also emphasizes the importance of building a web that is open and accessible to all rather than controlled by a few tech giants. Dash advocates for a renewed focus on the core values of the web, including decentralization, interoperability, and community-driven innovation.

title: The future of blogging
author: Koos Looijesteijn
description: Good things are coming to the web!
notes: Koos discusses the challenges and opportunities for bloggers in a rapidly evolving online landscape, emphasizing the importance of adapting to changing trends and technologies and creating high-quality content that provides value to readers. He also explores the potential for emerging technologies, such as artificial intelligence and virtual reality, to shape the future of blogging. I can get behind this.

title: Miley's Whole Career Has Been Building to This Moment
author: Rob Sheffield
description: Miley Cyrus' smash hit “Flowers”— and 'Endless Summer Vacation,' due Friday — are the culmination of one of pop's longest, most bizarre stories
notes: I'm so happy that Miley is finally getting her flowers. How has Miley evolved as an artist over the years? How has she succeeded despite her personal struggles? Will Endless Summer Vacation be a hit?

title: No, Blogging Is Not Dying Anytime Soon  - Darius Foroux
author: Darius Foroux
description: A well-known author said, “Blogging is dead. People only watch videos.” Sure, visual content is popular. But there are still people who read.
notes: The author argues against video content creators' claim that blogging is dead. Video is not my favourite way to consume information. I still enjoy a well-written article. The key takeaway is to spend your time doing the thing you like.

title: I don't want to log in to your website
author: Elizabeth Lopatto
description: Just say no to salesbros!
notes: This article examines how relying on tech giants for user authentication and advertising has complicated the web. Web developers should prioritise user privacy and find ways to reduce reliance on tech giants. I avoid participating with websites that push "login with x" prompts on me. I shouldn't have to log in to anything to read a simple page of text.

title: Dot-com – Vague, But Exciting
notes: This article briefly analyses the dot-com boom and bust between 1995 and 2001. It also looks into the rise of Amazon and how Bezos made it a success amidst the dot-com bust.

title: The Story Of How ODB Recorded His Verse For Mariah Carey’s Remix Is Fantastic
description: In 1995 Mariah Carey scored her ninth #1 single with "Fantasy." From her fifth album, Daydream, the song offered a nod to Grandmaster Flash and The Furious Five, by sampling…
notes: I've been enjoying season 3 of Wu-Tang: An American Saga and was reminded of this article while watching episode 7, Shadowboxin. This article recounts the hilarious way ODB's verse came to be on the Fantasy remix by Mariah Carey.

title: The Fight for the Open Web
description: Now that "the fight for the open web" is here, we must ask ourselves: how did Web3 come to dominate the conversation over previous initiatives? And what should we do about it?
notes: There’s no better time than now to fight for the freedom of the web. While web3 might not be the answer, it has brought the topic of web freedom to the forefront of discussion. Ultimately, the best way to fight for the web is to build. Build and participate in an open and free web!

title: Discover personal websites
author: sizeof(cat)
description: The year is 2023 and when you want to discover new personal websites on your favorite search engine, you just get bombarded with an endless stream of junk. If those are the alternatives, how do you reach out to those unique, fringy, weird and interesting websites? Well, I think I might have something to help you in your research.
notes: Another (hilarious) article emphasises the importance of website discovery. I'm nodding while reading, agreeing with the absolute state of search results. Provides some tips and resources for discovering new websites. Always be on the lookout for personal recommendations to find new exciting websites.

title: We Should Replace Facebook With Personal Websites
description: Personal websites and email can replace most of what people like about Facebook—namely the urge to post about their lives online.
notes: Personal websites and email can replace most of what people like about Facebook—namely the urge to post about their lives online. Why did we abandon personal websites in favour of the social network platform of the month?

title: The Story Behind Lil Kim’s Iconic Louis Vuitton Logo-Print Portrait
description: David LaChapelle tells us the whole history of how the image came together. Plus: a casino-themed Kardashian family Christmas card.
notes: The Story Behind Lil Kim’s Iconic Louis Vuitton Logo-Print Portrait

title: “I Realise Now How Harshly I Was Judged”: Miley Cyrus On Finding Her Peace – And Making The Album Of The Summer
author: Condé Nast
description: “I’ve been in the Garden of Eden before and I’ve taken the red apple, and it never feels good,” Cyrus tells British Vogue in an in-depth interview.
notes: Miley Cyrus' latest interview with British Vogue. Delve into this fascinating article to gain insights into the multi-talented artist's life, thoughts, and creative journey. How does she embrace authenticity and challenge societal norms? She shares her unique perspective on fashion, music, and personal growth.

title: For Katie Holmes, It’s Always Been About the Work
author: Condé Nast
description: She's got stellar personal style, an admirable ability to parent privately, and a seemingly permanent spot on the paparazzi's must-capture list. But behind it all, Katie Holmes is—and always has been—a passionate and successful actor and director.

title: Web rings: An alternative to search engines | Casey | College & Research Libraries News
description: Web rings: An alternative to search engines
notes: Looking to explore topic-specific websites in a more organised and engaging way? Travel back to 1998 and Check out this article that introduces the concept of web rings. Back then, they were described as interconnected universes of websites, allowing you to navigate between them and discover related content. Say goodbye to dead links and hello to a more efficient and curated online exploration!

title: The Strange Story of the Teens Behind the Mirai Botnet
description: Their DDoS malware threatened the entire Internet
notes: A look into the fascinating world of the Mirai botnet. Read about the origins, capabilities, and impacts of this infamous botnet, which wreaked havoc on the internet by compromising vulnerable IoT devices.

title: From the valley to the alley - The History of the Web
author: Jay Hoffmann
description: The Flatiron building is one of the most instantly recognizable buildings in New York City. Built at the beginning of […]

title: Tori Amos Bootleg Webring
site: GERTRUDE PRESS STANDS IN SOLIDARITY WITH BLACK LIVES MATTER, AND COMMITS TO CONTINUE TO FEATURE THE STORIES, ART AND VOICES OF THE BLACK QUEER AND TRANS PEOPLE WHO HAVE ALWAYS BEEN ON THE FRONT LINES OF REVOLUTION.
description: Once I was at a party when the music changed, drawing me from a sunny festive patio to the loudspeakers indoors. I hadn’t listened to this particular album in fifteen years, but knew every one of...
notes: The Tori Amos bootleg webring was a community of fans who collected and shared unofficial live recordings of Tori Amos concerts.

title: The Number Ones: Britney Spears’ “3”
description: In The Number Ones, I’m reviewing every single #1 single in the history of the Billboard Hot 100, starting with the chart’s beginning, in 1958, and working my way up into the present. Book Bonus Beat: The Number Ones: Twenty Chart-Topping Hits That Reveal the History of Pop Music.
notes: Britney Spears has bangers for days but only three have made it to number one. What?!

title: The Age of PageRank is Over | Kagi Blog
author: Vladimir Prelovac
description: When Sergey Brin and Larry Page came up with the concept of PageRank in their seminal paper The Anatomy of a Large-Scale Hypertextual Web Search Engine ( http://infolab.stanford.edu/pub/papers/google.pdf ) (Sergey Brin and Lawrence Page, Stanford University, 1998) they profoundly changed the way we utilize the web.
notes: Great read on the state of search. I'm going to give Kagi a try!

title: MACHETES DIPPED IN RUM
author: M
description: The Oral History of Bone Thugs-n-Harmony
notes: This is a super long read that goes into huge detail about Bone Thugs-N-Harmony all the way up to 2015.

title: Nostalgiamining vs. Forging the Future
description: Let's stop with the Geocities ripoffs already, alright?
notes: Some harsh truths here!

title: Neocities and a Lack of Passion
description: We need interesting people, now more than ever.

title: Revisiting "Passion"
description: A look back at my most contentious piece, "Neocities and a Lack of Passion".

title: Why I’m Leaving Neocities
notes: Biko shares why they've left Neocities

title: The State of Neocities
notes: Biko looks at the state of Neocities

title: A one-person oral history of Geocities HTML Chat
description: Geocities HTML Chat has been forgotten by the world. It is possible I am the only one who remembers it. I only half remember it.

title: Why Is the Web So Monotonous? Google.
author: Sandy Maguire
description: Discover the fascinating concept of the Monotonous Web.
notes:: embark on a thrilling journey into the Monotonous Web!

title: How Websites Die
author: Wesley Aptekar-Cassels
notes: The author looks to understand how websites die after researching defunct blogging platforms.

title: melankorin
notes: Kori sits down to think about what it takes to build a personal website.

title: Every person on the planet should have their own website 💡   Amin Eftegarie
notes: Every person on the planet should have their own website, on their own domain name, and blog about whatever they want.

title: My Journey Away from the JAMstack
description: The name is all but dead, nerfed by the company who invented it. Here’s why Netlify was ahead of its time and where everything went wrong.
notes: Interesting take, for now Netlify still does what I need it to do without issue so I’ll be sticking around. At least for now.

title: Splitting the Web
description: Splitting the Web écrit par Ploum, Lionel Dricot, ingénieur, écrivain de science-fiction, développeur de logiciels libres.

title: Building an iPod for 2022
description: I modified an old iPod Video with more storage, a new casing, and more battery life. Also some fancy software :)

title: Which iPod has the best quality audio? - Macintosh How To
author: Wayne
description: This article discusses the reasons for the difference in quality of the sound output of the various models of Apple iPod.

title: The Gamification of Reading Is Changing How We Approach Books
description: Since its inception in 2007, Goodreads has been a place where people can come together and rate their favorite books, find new authors, and more. This writer juggles the greater implications of the site with our current reading culture.

title: The Expanding Dark Forest and Generative AI
description: Proving you're a human on a web flooded with generative AI content

title: Interview with Kagi | DKB
description: The internet is run by adtech right now, and all the biggest companies are thriving on that, and I think the sooner we get out of that, the better. It is certainly going to be hard, and I'm not against ads per-se, but I'm against ads everywhere, ads by default, ads making our lives crappier and more miserable.
notes: The Internet is run by adtech, and all the big companies thrive on it. The sooner we don't have to deal with adtech, the better. Ads everywhere are the default and makes our Internet crappy and miserable.

title: The Birth and Death of the Yesterweb Forum Reveal Two Important Truths
description: While the death of the Yesterweb forum is a loss for the small web movement, it is symptomatic of greater problems.

title: The ‘90s Internet: When 20 hours online triggered an email from my ISP’s president
description: 1998 plea for restraint reveals a lost world where the 'Net was an opt-in experience.
notes: Yes. There was a time where you could be online too much. The author recalls in 1998, a plea for restraint from their ISP reveals a lost world where the Net was an opt-in experience.

title: A look at search engines with their own indexes
author: Rohan Kumar
description: A cursory review of all the non-metasearch, indexing search engines I have been able to find.
notes: The author, Seirdy, takes a look at all of the non-meta search, indexing search engines that they’ve been able to find. Published in November 2022, it’s amazing the number that are already no longer available.

title: The end of the Googleverse
author: Ryan Broderick
description: The last 25 years of Google’s history can be boiled down to a battle against the Google bomb. Is the search engine finally losing to its hijackers?
notes: “They were encouraging people to write on the web,” said Baio. Bloggers like Lenssen, Baio, and Beale felt like everything Google was doing was in service of making the internet better. The tools it kept launching felt tied to a mission of collecting the world’s information and helping people add more content to the web.

title: AOL Pretends to be the Internet - The History of the Web
description: In 1994, Ted Leonsis was the head of the new media marketing firm he created, Redgate Communications, spun out six […]
notes: AOL was always weird to me all the way down here in Aotearoa. I never understood how the trial disks made their way here. I was intrigued one day and installed the dialup configuration - it definitely did not work :joy:

title: Kagi Small Web | Kagi Blog
author: Vladimir Prelovac
description:
As a part of our ongoing pursuit to humanize the web, we are pleased to announce the launch of Kagi Small Web.

-----------------------
What is Kagi Small Web?
-----------------------

While there is no single definition, “small web” typically refers to the non-commercial part of the web, crafted by individuals to express themselves or share knowledge without seeking any financial gain.
notes: Great new Small Web features from Kagi! Unfortunately I’m not allowed to submit my own website though!

title: Small Web Connectivity
notes: One of the things social media took from us was a true sense of connection.

title: Marginalia Search receives FUTO Grant
description:
I’m happy to announce that the generous people at FUTO have granted the project $15,000 with no strings attached to help the search engine out with some more server power.
FUTO is a young Austin, TX-based organization “dedicated to developing, both through in-house engineering and investment, technologies that frustrate centralization and industry consolidation”. It’s one to keep an eye on, I believe their heart is in the right place and they have every possibility of making a real difference.
notes: Everybody’s favourite small web search engine receives a no strings grant to continue development. This means that the search engine will be able to move out of an apartment and into a rack in a data centre somewhere. Great news all round.

title: Did I Make a Mistake Selling My Social-Media Darling to Yahoo?
author: Jake Swearingen
description: Yahoo was negotiating to buy Facebook and Del.icio.us at the same time. Zuckerberg famously said no. Del.icio.us CEO Joshua Schachter said yes.
notes: Peak 2000s social bookmarking website (that was great fun) sold to and destroyed by Yahoo! Who else used Del.icio.us?

title: Best Practices When Using Fonts
description: Everything I know about best practices when using fonts on the web.
notes: A detailed post on web fonts, how to host your own, how to deal with unstyled content, variable fonts, subset fonts… Long but great read.

title: Kobo Libra 2
description: The website of Robin Rendle, a designer and writer from the UK.
notes: Mind blown, imagine if book readers supported RSS feeds?

title: The Quiet Web | by Brian Koberlein
author: Brian Koberlein
description: If you filter out websites with ads, trackers, and noise, what of the Internet remains?
notes: Another personal take on the quiet web. Touches upon adtech and how the quiet web avoids such nonsense. Once you get used to the quiet web, you may never want to go back.

title: The Best Time to Own a Domain Was 20 Years Ago, The Second Best Time Is Today
author: Jim Nielsen
description: Writing about the big beautiful mess that is making things for the world wide web.
notes: I'm a strong supporter of personal websites, and in my opinion, the first step before diving into your design or choosing hosting is securing your own domain name. As Jim discusses in the post, your domain can be your digital verification badge, adding an extra layer of authenticity to your online presence.

title: The OG Social Network: Other People’s Websites
author: Jim Nielsen
description: Writing about the big beautiful mess that is making things for the world wide web.
notes: What would the web be like today if Google hadn't killed Reader? Jim touches on that the web could have been our social netowrk. This is something that I talk about often and hope to see become a reality again.

title: Taylor Lorenz Extremely Online Book Interview | The Mozilla Blog
description: Here at Mozilla, we are the first to admit the internet isn’t perfect, but we know the internet is pretty darn magical. The internet opens up doors and o
notes: Great interview with Taylor Lorenz. I'm looking forward to getting my hands on and reading her new book, Extremely Online: The Untold Story of Fame, Influence, and Power on the Internet.

title: Rediscovering the Old Internet Vibe
author: Noisy Deadlines
description: The Internet is awesome because it connects computers, which can then connect people. This allows people to share information and work an...
notes: Another recount of someone finding those old Internet vibes.

title: My Kobo Customizations
description: Calibre Web syncing, new fonts, immersive reading, book covers, Pocket login, dark mode everywhere, Nickel Menu features
notes: A great post with lots of great customisations and hacks for the Kobo for when I make my eventual upgrade to the Libra 2

title: The internet used to be fun
notes: A continually updated collection of posts and blogs about the Internet. Lots of great reads in there, including my one of my own.

title: Old Web, New Web, Indie Web - petermolnar.net
author: Peter Molnar <mail@petermolnar.net>
description: If you have to decide on the order of creative freedom vs data ownership, what order do you choose?
notes: If you have to decide on the order of creative freedom vs data ownership, what order do you choose?

title: Simple Truths About Personal Websites · Matthias Ott – User Experience Designer
author: Matthias Ott
description: Matthias Ott is an independent user experience designer and developer from Stuttgart, Germany. Besides design practice he teaches Interface Prototyping at the Muthesius Academy of Fine Arts and Design, Kiel.
notes: Write. Publish. Enjoy.

title: Educational Sensational Inspirational Foundational
description: A historical record of foundational web development blog posts.
notes: A growing collection of blog posts and websites that are educational, sensational, inspirational, and foundational.

title: My Backup Strategy: Notes About Syncing to a Synology NAS
description: Background and Scope Data handling and backup can be hard, and everything below is my work-in-progress notes and effort towards achieving a system that works for me. Being self-employed in technolo…
notes: A reminder to myself to setup my back ups...

title: Internet Artifacts
description: Browse through the old internet
notes: Check this one out on your phone for the best experience!

title: It's 2023, here is why your web design sucks.
description: Exploring the reasons why we no longer have web designers.
notes: What happened to the web designer role?

title: Everything / Nothing
site: EASE.GG:  is mostly for your nostalgia for the 1980s, 1990s, and 2000s.
author: Erik August Johnson
description: A quick trip down memory lane looking at Everything / Nothing (E/N) websites, a trend from 20+ years ago.
notes: In the E/N world, the primary way of discovering more of these websites was through links from the sites you were already visiting.

title: Incredible Doom
description: Incredible Doom returns with Volume 3, introducing new characters and stories about finding connections in the wilds of the early web.
notes: A new comic series about finding connections in the wilds of the early web.

title: Carl and the cookie and the Web
description: It’s Friday and time for a story of the old Web, one man, and a cookie. A cookie which I still have almost 24 years later. Once upon a time there was a guy named Carl Steadman. ( Picture of C…
notes: A brief history of Carl Steadman of suck.com fame

title: Barriers to a more social IndieWeb – Tracy Durnell
notes: Blogging needs a different set of social norms than are in play on social media sites. Communication between websites faces many of the same social challenges as social media silos do, but adds additional impediments with technical hurdles and design differences.

title: The Internet of ghosts
description: When an incoming freshman at Harvard enters her room in the Yard for the first time, she's greeted with a little scrap of history meant to know
notes: In the early 2000s, the music sharing platform Napster allowed users to view other users' entire music libraries and discover new music. Browsing other users' music collections on Napster felt like exploring the personal libraries of strangers and discovering their musical tastes.
quote: If you wanted to, you could peer into a user’s hard drive – this was the fascinating part. When you found a song you’d long forgotten, or a rare b-side you never even knew existed, you could peruse the rest of the user’s music library and sample their tastes.

title: How Gaming Rigs Grew Up to Become Battle Stations
description: Tone-down the LEDs and turn-up the lumbar tension bar as gaming aesthetics age into the "battle station" era.
notes: How much time do you spend setting up your space rather than using it?

title: Paying tribute to the web with View Source
description: The web isn’t just another software platform. It’s the greatest software platform the world has ever seen. And yet even in its obvious glory, we’re still learning how to be grateful for all its con…
notes: Being able to view source on a web page back in the day was a great learning tool for myself and many others. Still is, that is why I don’t bother with minification to ensure my source is readable by anyone who is curious

title: What to Blog About When You Don’t Know What to Blog About
notes: I really like 13. “Here’s an interesting thing someone else has to say. Here’s my take on it.” I’d love to do more of 16. “This is what I’ve been reading/watching/listening to recently.”
quote: Here’s an interesting thing someone else has to say. Here’s my take on it. This is what I’ve been reading/watching/listening to recently.

title: The Village Effect of the Greater Web
description: Why do we confine ourselves to a handful of apps when the web is so gigantic?
notes: The corporate web is fucking up, big time. Except for perhaps TikTok (give it time), users have retreated to the DMs à la the "cozy web."

title: The UX of HTML - HTMHell
description: A collection of bad practices in HTML, copied from real websites.
notes: lol!
quote: Semantics and shit

title: Why are drive-thru menus so hard to read?
author: Hayden Donnell
description: It didn’t used to be this way. Why have things changed?
notes: I, too, am terrorised by the modern drive-thru experience. Unless I've planned ahead of visiting, I'll default to my standard order, missing out on any specials or deals.

title: I hate work. — Joan Westenberg
description: The piercing sound of my alarm shatters the stillness of my room at the ungodly hour of 5 AM, and I reluctantly drag myself out of bed. It’s the same daily grind, a routine I’ve been stuck in for years, first as a sound engineer, then as a tech exec, and now as an indie tech writer. I’m caught in th
notes: The idea of a work-life balance is a myth. It suggests that work should be as central to our lives as our passions, which is wrong. The truth is this. Work is not my passion. And that’s okay.
quote: If given the choice, I would gladly banish it forever. Given the choice, I’d spend hours leisurely lounging by the pool, engrossed in Agatha Christie novels, sipping on ice-cold Diet Coke until noon.

title: blakewatson.com  –  omg.lol: an oasis on the internet
description: If you enjoyed the old web of the 90s and 00s; if you love tinkering with your personal website; or if you just like quirky, fun things on the internet, you will love this.
notes: omg.lol is a gateway into the fun side of the web. It is one of many places on the modern web doing things right.

title: My complete blogging workflow | Michael Harley
description: Here is my complete blogging workflow from how I manage ideas all the way to publishing and sharing.
notes: I love reading about other peoples workflows. Michael provides great detail into his, with a similar tech stack. I almost want to try hosting my site on a VPS again. The front matter extension sounds like a great addition as I’m not currently populating time attributes to my posts and this causes issues with my feeds when I post multiple times a day!

title: Please, Expose your RSS
description: Please, expose your RSS.
notes: Expose your RSS feed. I have a link up the top, and down below.

title: Choosing a Green Web Host
notes: I’ve always been interested in green web hosting but it seems difficult to determine whether or not a host really is “green”…

title: Let us forget that the internet exists.
description: This is what I am saying: Let us all quit social media. Let us all look up from our phones and ask our loved ones how they are. Let us start our days by looking out the window if we can. Let us sta…
notes: Let us forget that the internet exists

title: A Linux evening
notes: This was a fantastic read, the quote above sums it up nicely.
quote: The author, dkozel, never came back to answer. I imagine they typed the solution on a 40% keyboard featuring unmarked keys and then rolled into the sunset on a Segway for which they had compiled the kernel themselves. Completely oblivious of their awesomeness and of how many people would later find solace in their prose.

title: Patterns for Personal Web Sites
description: Guidelines for creating a living personal Web site.
notes: Patterns for creating personal web sites. Last updated in 2009, a lot of the page still rings true.

title: The Web is Fantastic
description: No not that web. The real web.
notes: The Web is fantastic. I agree with Robb. He covers a lot of stuff that makes the Web a fantastic place. If you read my site, you'll see me saying the same things!
quote: The real web, the small web, the indie web is amazing. Don't give Facebook and the rest of these clowns your content. Don't give them the time or your attention. Get a blog, a website, a Mastodon account, something you control, and share links to cool things you find. Make a list of your favourite blogs or websites or photos of cats. Write about a pizza you had that was delicious. Share a recipe. Go down a rabbit hole for hours on end adding weird stuff to your site. Just do it somewhere you control because the real web is fantastic.

title: The Internet Is About to Get Weird Again
author: Anil Dash
description: The internet seems ripe for change, and millions of people seem poised to connect in new ways, as they reconsider their relationship to technology.
notes: I’m all for more small scale web projects being created this year. More cool services like omg.lol is what the Web needs!

title: The Guiding Principles of My Personal Website
notes: "Core Website Tenets" focus on the mindsets of website building rather than the technical workflows or frameworks. They lean towards handcrafting everything from the html on the pages, to the graphics and other assets to the intentional thinking of how each page is crafted and conveys information.

title: Ashton
notes: Early sites had links pages that connected to other sites, forming a network of linked pages in the true spirit of the web. Modern sites have become isolated and do not link out to other sites, which goes against the original vision of the interconnected web.
quote: The first proposal for the world wide web was written in March 1989 by Tim Berners-Lee. The idea was to create a web of hypertext documents which could be viewed by anyone with a computer and a browser made specifically for viewing things in this web.

title: Why Personal Websites are Important | Chuck Carroll
notes: I can't stop talking about the benefits of having a personal website over relying on social media profiles. With social media platforms you're at the mercy of entities that do not care about you. Creating and maintaining personal websites allow you to develop new personal skills. Build more websites.
quote: Your website should be the primary place where all of the stuff you create goes. It should be THE place for people to find and communicate with you.

title: The Year For Blogging To Pump Up The Volume
description: In 1990, New Line Cinema released a box office failure starring Christian Slater as a teenage pirate radio DJ who inspires a surge of others to take to the air and find their voice. Come and gone n…
notes: "There’s been a lot of pontificating lately that the web is ripe for a blogging renaissance, wishing for it to be true. Much of it from people who don’t seem to notice that’s it’s already begun. Maybe they don’t anymore know quite where to look."

title: Static Site Generator Cheat Sheet & FAQ
description: One person is typing.
notes: Cassie added a little page to their site to jot down the answers to those questions when they find them, with an easy URL to bookmark. Fantastic idea!

title: EveryoneShouldBlog.txt
description: Everyone Should Blog, And That Includes You
notes: Xandra want's more out of blogs than just technical topics. Any life no matter how mundane is worth blogging about.
quote: i want and wish for more people feel like they themselves can be what they show the world—not just their work or their projects. i want to read your thoughts, your feelings, your perceptions of the world as it's happening around you.

title: Neatnik Notes · The power to _not_
notes: I sometimes find myself in front of a comment or a post that screams for a response. The best thing I can do is leave it alone.
quote: The kindest thing you can do for yourself is to just not engage. Leave it alone. Go look at something else that’s nice instead, and forget about it.

title: The web is yours | James' Coffee Blog
description: The web is yours.
notes: If you haven't got the message yet, James has more convincing for you to start your own website.

title: NoTechSaviors.txt
description: No Tech Saviors in Hobbyist Spaces
notes: Xandra talks about creating and encouraging more welcoming environments in the small/personal/open/indie web space. Remember, nobody really cares if you're an expert, just be chill.

title: Your site, your home, your web • Cory Dransfeldt
description: A brief, perhaps unoriginal, plea to have fun sharing and building on the web.
notes: Cory looks at how the fracturing of social media platforms has created an opportunity for people to explore new ways of self-expression online with a personal website or blog as a great outlet. Our personal websites allow us a place of sharing and connecting with others. If you know how to build for the web, help by sharing that knowledge.

title: gilest.org: Make the indie web easier
notes: I agree that creating and publishing for the web needs to be easier for **everyone**, not just developers. But are more tools the best way to go about it?

title: Digital Legacy Trust, New Zealand
description: Digital Legacy Trust, New Zealand
notes: An approach to perserving your online legacy

title: 2024 is the Year of the Blog
description: The Bored Horse, written by Thord D. Hedengren, explores the intersection between technology and culture, with all that entails.
notes: Lots of people are getting noisy about 2024 being the year of blogging. I'm all for it, but I also want more than blogs to start popping again.

title: You Should Have a Website | maerk.xyz
description: People don’t really make personal websites anymore. The homepage of Squarespace makes it obvious that most people use websites for business and social media for “themselves.” Maybe I’m the weird one, but I think having a digital canvas where you can do anything you can think of is the coolest shit ever. For most people, different combinations of social media websites have replaced the need for a personal website, but they are not the same thing.
notes: Build more websites!
quote: People don’t really make personal websites anymore

title: tool and die » saturn.town
notes: Celebrating simple tools

title: The quest for purging my bookmarks - Łukasz Wójcik, Blog
description: In January 2023 I woke up to my browser bar containing dozens, if not hundreds, of unsorted links I never touched again.
notes: I think it's time to nuke my browser bookmarks and pocket reading list and close all open tabs...

title: The State of the Independent Web 2022: Updated 2024
description: About this update: This is an update of an article from 2022. There have been enough improvements in 2 years to warrant an update! 2024 updates are in red. Some items have not changed enough to be…
notes: There is a gap for hosted tools; what could we do in this space? Overall, the independent and open web is looking healthy.
quote: Directories have come and gone, and new search engines have appeared. Blogrolls, links pages and RSS feeds are making a come back. Static website hosts continue to appear. Forums are back. There is a gap for hosted tools

title: LongLiveWebpages.txt
description: over the past couple of weeks, i've been pleasantly surprised at discourse popping up on my feeds, surrounding creating your own blog, making the independent...
notes: Xandra has shared another thought-provoking post as a follow-up to last week's internet discourse on making the web more accessible. Xandra talks about websites that go beyond a simple blog. This made me think that an About page would be unnecessary if we filled our websites with our interests. Web surfers would quickly get a better idea of who we are from the pages on our websites than they could from a couple of lines on an About page.

title: Remembering the early 00s teen website scene - localghost
description: A new theme for localghost.dev, and with it, a look back at the blogs we used to build in the early 00s.
notes: Sophie takes a trip down memory lane to an era of the web that I thought was much cooler than the Geocities era before and definitely cooler than the MySpace era that came after it.

title: How I deploy my Eleventy site to Neocities - localghost
description: My setup for automatically deploying my Eleventy site to Neocities from GitHub.
notes: Last week I said there needs to be more 11ty tutorials outside of Netlify. Sophie drops this one for deploying to Neocities. A great look into her 11ty to Neocities workflow (the same as mine!)

title: Please, don’t force me to log in
site: Juha-Matti Santala - Community Builder. Dreamer. Adventurer.
author: Juha-Matti Santala
description: The current accelerating trend of requiring accounts and logins for everything has to stop.
notes: I lose interest when an application or service requires me to create an account for no reason. I won't provide my information for vague \"better experience\" promises. Juhis drops straight facts in this post.
quote: It feels like everything these days needs you to create an account and log in to use them. These examples go on and on and on. What’s common with all of them, is that they are all services and software that don’t need logins and accounts.

title: Online anonymity: study found ‘stable pseudonyms’ created a more civil environment than real user names
author: Alfred Moore
description: A higher quality discussion emerged among commenters allowed to use personas instead of their real names.
notes: An interesting study. My online interactions are done with my fLaMEd pseudonym, which is common in the communities where I participate. My experience with interactions with others under pseudonyms has been overwhelmingly positive, as we value our online handles. I love the freedom of expressing myself in my online spaces without being tied to my real life identity.
quote: The ability to remain anonymous when commenting online is a double-edged sword. It is valuable because it enables people to speak without fear of social and legal discrimination. But this is also what makes it dangerous. Someone from a repressive religious community can use anonymity to talk about their sexuality, for example. But someone else can use anonymity to hurl abuse at them with impunity.

title: This website is personal - Frills
description: My thoughts, my feelings, my perceptions
notes: Don't worry Frills, you're not the only one who experiences this.
quote: Sometimes, I come up with a banger of a blog post idea, only to find myself grappling with writing the content, and eventually adding it to my increasing pile of forgotten drafts.

title: A rant on ARC Search – Manu
description: I was listening to the most recent Vergecast episode last night and an interview with Josh Miller, CEO of The Browser Company, makers of the ARC …
notes: Hard agree. I enjoy a good spam free search. The six pages in the example are all sites I’d actively avoid. Small, independent search is the way to go.
quote: The problem with search is that it’s full of fucking spam and ads. That’s the problem with search. The solution to search is not to “reinvent the browser” or to use AI to power searches for you. The solution to search is a search engine that is aligned with the users.

title: Why I Blog. You Should Too!
author: Michael Sass
description: Scream into the void...
notes: Mike shares encouragement and tips on why you should blog and how to get going.
quote: You should start a blog. If you disagree, I certainly understand the hesitancy. I was once like you! I’m here to convince you otherwise.

title: You don't need to be an expert to write | James' Coffee Blog
description: Matthias Ott's recent article on writing caught my attention:
notes: If we were all experts our websites would be boring.

title: Which self is this?
description: Last month Katherine called out the tension inherent in a “personal” website which is that it is both public and personal, and one’s public (or professional) persona is often different from that of their personal life. Robin Rendle riffed on the concept and said that it’s totally fine for personal websites to be messy or imperfect or weird (i.e., not necessarily how you’d want to present a “professional” front) and declared, in a pretty great and punchy/pithy statement, “You’re a poem and not software”.
notes: Rachel shares her journey about growing up extremely online. She shares how personas change from using aliases to hiding behind the walls of social media to finally being comfortable with letting her personal and professional lives intersect online. It's wild how similar Rachel's journey has been to mine; I love reading about other people's experiences and finding the similarities in our journeys. However, I'm still perfectly happy sitting behind my alias and not matching my personal to professional life. I can't wait to dive in and share my journey.
quote: Like knowing to use an alias to represent my online persona in my first era, I instinctively knew before and during medical school that my online self, who, while earnest and genuine was also a bit messy and still figuring herself out, was not and never could be the self that was expected to show up to see patients.

title: Why Personal Blogging Still Rules
author: Mike Grindle
notes: This post explores the history of personal blogging, its decline, and eventual revival. Personal blogs and websites used to be a popular means of online expression before social media platforms gained dominance. These websites enabled us to form authentic connections and communities. I've said it before, and I'll repeat it. Let's create more personal websites and blogs to revive the culture of authentic online communities.
quote: Remember when personal blogging was a thing? I don’t mean those things tacked on to business sites or any of that ad-riddled click-bait junk. No, I mean blogs that existed to be, well, blogs. If you are under the age of thirty, you perhaps don’t. But let me tell you, kid - blogs were hella cool. Yet for the longest time, I thought that era was dead and gone. That personal blogs had gone the way of the dodo or the fansite. But I was wrong.

title: Blogging Isn't Dead. It Never Died. It's Never Going to Die. Neither Is Personal Blogging - Jeffrey Pillow
description: Remember blogging? That thing a blogger on the Internet declared dead twelve years ago not realizing they were, in fact, blogging at that very moment even
notes: While some have declared blogging dead over the years, Jeffrey reminds us blogging has never really died and remains an essential part of internet culture. Like me, he advocates for a return to more personal, authentic blogging and writing online and owning one's domain rather than relying on platforms.
quote: Blogging isn't dead. Punk rock isn't dead. Zip it.

title: The Unbearable Sameness of the Modern Web
description: The Unbearable Sameness of the Modern Web
notes: When did everything start looking the same online?
quote: Also, it’s BORING. It’s BORING AS HELL. Guh, bring back interesting websites, bring back the creativity that the web offers. Bring back frontend devs who aren’t afraid to get down with the mouse event handlers!!

title: Breaking up with Slack and Discord: why it's time to bring back forums. — Joan Westenberg
description: When I first found my people online, forums were the main way people gathered to discuss shared interests. Web-based bulletin boards allowed members to have ongoing, asynchronous conversations over days or weeks as participants logged in to read and respond on their own schedule. Topics were neatly
notes: Over at the Cafe we've realised the same thing. However we're kick starting our own forum, check it out at https://discourse.32bit.cafe/
quote: The heyday of forums may have passed over a decade ago as real-time chat emerged. But it's time for deeper online discussion to make a thoughtful comeback.

title: The Teenage Web
notes: Louie recounts their early experiences on the internet in the 2000s. Like many others, he experienced social networks like MySpace and Twitter, which centralised online communities. At the same time, forums and personal websites became less common. While these platforms made it easier to connect with others, Louie laments the commercialisation of the internet through targeted ads and less focus on individual interests and niche communities.
quote: >Welcome to the Corporate Internet. It didn’t used to be like this. The web used to be a collection of independently-operated sites that we all individually controlled. We used to be so punk rock about the web.

title: Towards a quieter, friendlier web • Cory Dransfeldt
description: I love the internet, I grew up on it and (probably) spend too much time on it. I found the music I love on it, I've made friends on it, I went to school for business but built a career on the web instead. I often have a hard time reconciling where the web is now with what it was like when I first dove into it.
notes: Great post from Cory. Avoid the noise, avoid the nonsense!
quote: Be kind, be honest and engage on your own terms. Walk away from anything that doesn't serve you and don't be afraid to craft a browsing experience that best suits you. A healthier web is one that's slower, friendly and serves you. Eschew things that make demands of you, insist or impose upon your time and attention.

title: The Subversive Hyperlink
author: Jim Nielsen
description: Writing about the big beautiful mess that is making things for the world wide web.
notes: Lucky for us, who curate web experiences from the comfort of our homepages, we have no worries sharing any link we find interesting and exciting and want to share.
quote: To some, the hyperlink is dangerous and must be controlled:

title: Make a Damn Website
notes: This post dives into the importance of autonomy over presenting yourself online. Stop relying on third-party sites spread across the web for your work, profiles or portfolios. Those sites might be convenient, but they do not give you control of yourself and often become problematic. How frustrating is it when a business's details are locked behind the walls of a social media page? Build a damn website, damnit!
quote: I believe it’s everyone’s imperative to genuinely invest in making websites again. For ourselves, for our businesses, for our interests.

title: Give me a web feed or an API for everything • Cory Dransfeldt
description: If I'm using your service, if I'm paying for your service, I really need it to have an API or a web feed.
notes: Too real for me at the moment. Agree wtih Cory as per usual. If I'm using your service, you better be giving me access to my own data!
quote: If I'm using your service, if I'm paying for your service, I really need it to have an API or a web feed.

title: Send links to your friends and make the Web a better place
description: The missing part of web ressurgence
notes: Do you remember when the internet didn't have Google or other algorithms and platforms to push content on us? Back then, we used to share links with our friends over IMs or IRC; we knew them by their screen names. One of my favourite things was to visit Yahoo! and check out the new websites added to my favourite categories. Despite having few tools, we managed to navigate the web just fine. So, don't hesitate to continue sharing links with your friends; they'll appreciate it.
quote: The small web is born from passion, not from chase of profit. Only we can make it flourish like it used to flourish. Simply sending a cool link from time to time to your friends is enough.

title: The state of the web in 2024. Novelty. Booms & busts. The joy of simple HTML-centric web design. Personal websites. The centralized, walled web vs. the decentralized web.
description: It’s ironic it appears EEE, enshittification or homogenization (or whatever you want to call it) could potentially be the downfall (not the INSTANT end of, but maybe just a crawl into obsoles…
notes: A growing number of people are leaving the walled gardens of the web to find a better experience. Websites don't need to be flashy and overly complicated to be effective; they simply need to deliver information quickly, reliably and without distractions.
quote: Even though a lot of people use large, popular walled web and/or social media services now and still will in the future, there’s a percentage of people who will stop using them. To me, it feels like there’s a clear fracturing happening on the web right now like never before.

title: Read-it-Later vs Hoarding.
description: This morning, 10 minutes ago to be exact, I had the crazy idea of getting a Pinboard account. Why, you may ask? Well, there's this idea out there that you might want to hoard links...
notes: The struggles of read-it-later services. Are you actually going to read that link or just hoard them until the end of the web?
quote: I barely manage my read-it-later bucket, in fact, I don't think I ever look at it, so why hoard links I am never going to look back?

title: Can We Please Put an End to Overperformed Audiobooks?
description: Britney Spears is perfect and her nasal voice with a Southern accent and just the right touch of vocal fry is perfect. Which is why I was so surprised to hear Michelle Williams, an actress who is a…
notes: As a big audiobook reader/listener, I've noticed this while trying to get lost in a story, even more so after reading this article. When the narrator creates a different voice for each character, it ruins my ability to imagine what they sound like, as I have done for years of reading analogue books. Don't get me started on the accents; they're unnecessary.
quote: Please just read me a story without distraction. I don’t need to hear a variety of voices from a single narrator if a full-cast production is not in the cards.

title: Apple Annie’s Weblog · Give your blog a name.
author: Anne Sturdivant (@anniegreens)
description: With the initial Blogroll + two spins under my belt, I see some trends and I'm missing some names!
notes: Apple Annie wants you to name your blog. While you're at it, stop using your face as your open-graph image too :P
quote: Your blog's name is more than you! Your blog is an extension of you and takes on a form itself. Your blog is the best parts of you because you are putting things on your blog that you probably don't put out anywhere else in this world. That's pretty special and your blog deserves a name.

title: Using the iPad as an iPad
description: Using my iPad as just an iPad has helped me reset my thinking on wants vs. needs when it comes to specs and accessories as well as to rediscover the joys and simplicity of the platform again.
notes: This post discusses rediscovering the joy of using an iPad, as an iPad. I'm experiencing a similar discovery after a couple of years of trying to use my iPad as a laptop replacement. It can get you some of the way there, but not the whole way. Some of the workarounds are wild and take away the experience of using the device as it should be.
quote: Using my iPad as just an iPad has helped me reset my thinking on wants vs. needs when it comes to specs and accessories as well as to rediscover the joys and simplicity of the platform again.

title: Sharing links via RSS, sharing links via APIs • Cory Dransfeldt
description: I follow and subscribe to a whole bunch of blogs and less and less high-volume news via RSS. It's one of my absolute favorite mediums for keeping up with and reading content on the web.
notes: Cory explains his process of subscribing to RSS feeds and utilising APIs to automate the sharing of links through his website and Mastodon. This practice facilitates the discovery and distribution of links that platforms cannot control. The beauty of the web lies in our ability to share links freely across our websites, allowing for an independent, distributed, and enjoyable experience.
quote: It's encouraging to see more and more folks sharing links, boosting them and blogging them. It makes discovery easier when it's done cooperatively.

title: I Was a Teenage Webmaster
author: Mike Grindle
notes: Towards a more personal web
quote: The internet is not a place I visit anymore. It is an obligation that follows me everywhere like a shadow, ever-hungry for my attention.

title: Only 90s Web Developers Remember This
author: Zach Holman
description: Written pieces, talks, and other bits by Zach Holman.
notes: A look back into how we did things in the 90s

title: The Easiest Way to Start Blogging
description:
So, you’re interesting in blogging but don’t know where to start?
I’ve put together this list of blogging platforms that do not require any knowledge of codi...
notes: Good overview of current blogging platforms, their costs and features.
